stem: The patient's fundal height is at the umbilicus, consistent with approximately _____ weeks gestation.

rationale.correct: At 20 weeks gestation, the fundal height typically reaches the level of the umbilicus. This is due to the growing uterus expanding upwards into the abdominal cavity as the fetus develops. Measuring fundal height is a standard part of prenatal care to assess fetal growth and development. Deviation from expected fundal height can indicate the need for further investigation.

mnemonic.name: Umbilicus at 20
mnemonic.description: Remember 'Umbilicus at 20' to recall that the fundal height is usually at the umbilicus around 20 weeks gestation.

rationale.incorrect: At 36 weeks, the fundus is typically at the xiphoid process. This is much higher than the umbilicus and indicates a later stage of pregnancy. The fundal height progresses predictably as the pregnancy advances, allowing healthcare providers to monitor fetal growth and identify potential issues such as intrauterine growth restriction or macrosomia.

questionTrap.reason: Students may not have memorized the correlation between fundal height and gestational age at various landmarks, leading them to select an incorrect gestational age. This requires recall of specific anatomical landmarks and their association with gestational age.
questionTrap.commonMistake: Confusing fundal height with different gestational ages, especially at different anatomical landmarks. For example, confusing the umbilicus with the symphysis pubis or xiphoid process.

clinicalPearls: Fundal height measurement is a quick and easy way to assess fetal growth during prenatal visits. It provides a general estimate of gestational age and fetal development.
Fundal height should correlate with gestational age within +/- 2 cm. Significant deviations warrant further investigation to rule out potential complications.

Factors such as multiple gestation, polyhydramnios, or fetal growth restriction can affect fundal height measurements. These conditions can alter the expected correlation between fundal height and gestational age.

itemContext.sbar:
14:00, SBAR communication:
Situation: Patient is a 28-year-old female, G1P0 at 20 weeks gestation, presenting for a routine prenatal visit.
Background: Patient reports feeling well and denies any complaints of pain, bleeding, or leaking of fluid. She has been following a healthy diet and taking prenatal vitamins.
Assessment: Fetal heart tones auscultated at 140 bpm. Fundal height is at the umbilicus, which is consistent with 20 weeks gestation. No edema or signs of preeclampsia noted.
Recommendation: Continue routine prenatal care. Schedule next appointment in four weeks. Discuss gestational diabetes screening at the next visit. Provide education on fetal movement counting.

Situation: Patient is a 28-year-old female, G1P0 at 20 weeks gestation, presenting for a routine prenatal visit.
Background: Patient reports feeling well and denies any complaints of pain, bleeding, or leaking of fluid. She has been following a healthy diet and taking prenatal vitamins.
Assessment: Fetal heart tones auscultated at 140 bpm. Fundal height is at the umbilicus, which is consistent with 20 weeks gestation. No edema or signs of preeclampsia noted.
Recommendation: Continue routine prenatal care. Schedule next appointment in four weeks. Discuss gestational diabetes screening at the next visit. Provide education on fetal movement counting.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: Vitals: Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg Heart Rate: 80 bpm Respiratory Rate: 16 breaths/min Temperature: 98.6°F (37°C) Oxygen Saturation: 99% on room air

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Labs: CBC: Within normal limits Urinalysis: Negative for protein and glucose Rubella: Immune Blood Type: O positive

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: Physical Exam: General: Patient is alert and oriented, in no acute distress. HEENT: Normal appearance. Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm, no murmurs. Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen: Fundal height at umbilicus, fetal heart tones auscultated at 140 bpm. Extremities: No edema.

tabs.content: No radiology reports available for this visit.

tabs.content: Medication Administration Record: Prenatal Vitamins: One tablet daily
